description.text:
This is a tool to use your smartphone flash as a projector to make shadows and tell stories to the kids. You will need a toiler paper tube to make it, so it's kinda a recycle project too :)

There is three files:

  • Main Pieces, the ones you need to make the tool. Use support to print.
  • Scenes, the ones whom make shadows
  • For new Scenes, a template to make your own shadows.

Feel free to add new scenes, and if you like, send it to me so I can add it to this project.

Esta es una herramienta para usar el flash del celular para hacer sombras y usarlas para contar historias a los chicos. Necesitás un tubo de papel higienico para hacerlo, asi que depaso reciclamos un poco :)

Hay tres archivos:

  • Main Pieces, las que hacen la herramienta. Usa soporte para imprimirla.
  • Scenes, las distintas escenas para contar historias
  • ForNewScenes, para hacer tus propias escenas.

Si haces nuevas escenas, y si queres, enviamelas así las agrego a este proyecto.

description.text:
Now you can have your own BF1 Limpet Charge to throw at your friends and run away! I designed it to be 7.25" in diameter for the body so anyone with an 8" or larger printer can make this without scaling. The parts will need to be bonded together with some form of adhesive; use whatever you like. Clear silicone and super glue work well. For extra coolness you can put some magnets on the bottom and stick it on the fridge.

Print the quantity of parts as follows:
1x Limpet Body - Army Green
1x Key - Metallic
1x Base Center - Metallic
1x Base Magnet - Black
4x Handle Base - Army Green
4x Handle Radius Connector - Metallic
2x Handle Grip - Wood Fill

author: Colleen

title: Spiral Chess Set - Enclosed Cross Sections

description.text:
I made this chess set based on the classic spiral design.

This one is unique in a special way. I was not happy with the jump and print process associated with the cross sections of each slice. This version makes every layer of every piece a complete closed surface. This removes a lot of the little strings between sections and improves the structural integrity. I added little screw holes on the bottom so you can attach a weighted/felt base as well.

Designed with Onshape

I designed this with onshape. I used a common stem based on parameters and added the various tops and augmented heights for each piece.

Jellybox

I designed this set to test my new printer, the IMade3D Jellybox. I can print a full set in about 4 hours with PLA.

This was my first try at a Customizer print. I didn't realize that the STL files I need to attach don't work yet in Customizer. I guess you need to have OpenSCAD, download all my files, then export as STL to print. If anyone knows how to get around this, please let me know.  
I made a customizable iPhone holder that clips into the vent of a 2013-2014 Mazda CX-5. This should allow you to customize the phone holding part to fit your case or bumper, if you use one. The part that fits the car is not customizable, as this would be incredibly difficult to make it work for any car. So, if you have the same care as me, I hope this works out for you. Please follow all applicable laws for driving and cell phone usage.

Once printed, the 2 side channels need to be glued on. I made them very easy to glue with a portion of each channel that hugs the side, and another part that sits on the face. You can put superglue along the channel and put it right in place without any guesswork. To install this in the car, close the vent (push the louvers down) and put the top and side clips in first, then rotate the device clockwise to snap in the bottom clip. The spine in the back should sit along a seam to the left of the plastic dash. See images of my installed device. Please follow all applicable laws for driving and cell phone usage.

Hi guys,

I've been trying others supports but all have some issues, so i've been designing my personal support for the 18mm inductive sensor. And this is the result.

  • Auto leveling support based on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2001681

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Skynet 3D (Marlin) configuration
  • V1:

Z Probe position:

 #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1
 #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -61
 #define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach):

 #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION   31
 #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION  191
 #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION   159
 #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION  30
  • V2:

Z Probe position:

 #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1
 #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -64
 #define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach):

 #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION   31
 #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION  191
 #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION   156
 #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION  30

Note: This is my configuration, it's good for me. Try this or use your personal configuration :)

print_settings.Notes:: Print this at 5-10% or more if you aren't willing to waste to much plastic, but you don't need to have any more than 10% to test the tolerance. you don't need a raft because of the flat base to help adhesion to your bed. you don't need any supports as long as you have the hole facing up in order for no overhangs.

description.text: This cube is a tolerance test for your printer. This cube is 1in X1in X 1in. The hole in the middle is .5in X .5in X .5in. This will test the tolerance of your printer after you print this measure the cube and the hole that will show the tolerance of your printer. The tolerance will be helpful when designing pieces that fit together. if you don't account for the tolerance the pieces probably wont fit together.

Printer:

Maker Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

5-10%

Notes:

Print this at 5-10% or more if you aren't willing to waste to much plastic, but you don't need to have any more than 10% to test the tolerance. you don't need a raft because of the flat base to help adhesion to your bed. you don't need any supports as long as you have the hole facing up in order for no overhangs.

Measure, no sanding

After printing this don't sand the block because if you do that the test would be pointless because you wouldn't be able to tell the precise tolerance. After printing just measure the cube on all sides and see how much excess there is.
This was obviously a very simple design and was created in minutes in Fusion 360.

description.text:
First of, please note I do not own this model, it is just fan made for personal use. Due to the modding support for the game "Sins of a Solar Empire" I was able to use the original model and rework it for 3D printing. The first image shown is from the wiki page for reference in painting the model.

For printing, print one of each piece, as well as nine (9) copies of the KolTurret model. I enjoy kits so for more fun and extra detail I separated the ship into multiple parts. If printing in PLA, glue with epoxy. If printing in ABS, use ABS glue or epoxy.

author: Benifir

description.text:
For more information visit - http://goo.gl/16euPi
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/Proto3000
Google+ - https://plus.google.com/+Proto3000/posts Proto3000's 3D Printed Snow Globe is here. Feel free to download and customize the snow globe to your liking. If you'd like to see how we did it, visit: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=90Kl7kMS6Fs Our snow globe was created using a combination of applications including: Polyjet, FDM, and Makerbot technologies.

We started by designing the components of the snowglobe using Solidworks CAD software and designed the globe with threads to securely screw the lid to the base.   
The next step was to send the files to print. We used different additive processes for the prints to showcase the synergy that the technologies have with one another, and the different material properties that can be achieved. VeroClear to create the clear glass-like globe. VeroWhite for the base too add strength while remaining waterproof, and the Snowman itself was printed on a makerbot using PLA plastic for speed and finishing.  
Once the prints were complete, some finishing is required. support material is washed away using a water jet, and brushes for finer details. The globe is  then sanded down and clear coated to create transparency. The snowman was simply spray painted white, and the eyes and nose were hand painted.  After clearcoating, the parts are ready to go.  
Once the printed parts have been finished, the last step is the assembly. The Snowman is glued to the base, a small amount of epoxy is applied to the threads,  and the globe is screwed into the base. through a small hole in the bottom, the globe is filled with water and then plugged to seal the water in.  
There you have it, a 3D printed snowglobe.

title: Satellite Speaker Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Lost a speaker mount in your last move? Worry not! Just print one of each STL. Fasteners you'll need:

  • M5-0.8 x 20 mm Machine Screw, Qty 2
  • M5-0.8 Nylon Lock Nut, Qty 1
  • No.6 x .25" Machine Screw, Qty 1
  • No.6 Machine Screw Nut, Qty 1

Be careful of print orientation, and don't use these for anything but light satellite speakers. Prints can separate along the layers and drop your speaker. Also this works best for speakers at ear level; this mount won't allow you to angle the speaker up or down.

The one shown was printed in PETG and spray painted.

This just a small mod to the alrdy awesome SkyNet3D firmware.
Made it primary fo the ANET A8 but It should work on all Printers that uses the LCD2004 Display (20 Chars x 4 Lines)

It does only one thing:
It replaces the, in my opinion useless, SD-Print-Percentage in the Display with the FAN-Speed of the part cooling Fan.

How to install

(This is for the LATEST Skynet3D firmware which is 2.3.2_fix2
If you need this mod for a earlier version, send me a message!)

Replace the 2 files in your SkyNet3D firmware folder
Configuration_adv.h
ultralcd_impl_HD44780.h

The Display of the Fan-Speed instead of SD-Print-Percentage is enabled by default, however you can change it back to the old SD-Print-Percentage by comment out the line 569 in the Configuration_adv.h file like this:

// #define DISPLAY_FAN_SPEED

Upload to your printer and done!

Have fun and Happy Printing!

Moo,
Otter

description.text:
To start from scratch, to get the best 360° videos in tight spaces, you have to get the lenses as close together as possible. In these two configurations you get as close as it gets with the GoPros.

To assemble, I used a m3 screw with hex head, a washer and some knurled nuts. On both rigs the bottom thread is a 1/4" nut, to get standard tripod mounts to the rig.

Upsides on these rigs compared to others: rig with 3 cameras can actually record [email protected] on the GoPro settings, get the cams out of the rigs tool-free, have possibilities to get to the usb while mounted. Change battery on GoPro4 while mounted on the rig with 3 cams, perfect metal thread on the tripod

All you need to do is do modify the GoPro Cameras to 220° or wider lens. Prefered GoPro 3+ black and 4 black.

author: dricketts

description.text:
The .step and .iges files show all the plumbing fittings used, 10' long 3" diameter barrel surrounded by a 6" diameter pressure chamber 8' long, with a piston valve at the rear. 3D printed spacer keeps the 3" schedule 40 pvc barrel centered up in the 6" schedule 40 pvc pressure chamber. At the breech, a 1" pipe connects to a modified sprinkler valve, which dumps the air from behind the piston to suck it backward, allowing all air pressurized to 90psi in the chamber to now slam out through the barrel. A full pop can, placed in the sabot (printed with flexible TPU, like the valve) will be accelerated to roughly 500fps, with more muzzle energy than a 12ga shotgun. I am only posting this for information that is interesting, and I do not recommend anyone build this, because it will launch things farther than you can see, which could be dangerous if not used properly.

-- BUILD NOTES --

Fittings and materials needed:
All fittings should be Schedule 40 and/or list "PW", especially 6" fittings
10 feet of 3" schedule 40 pvc tube
10 feet of 6" schedule 40 pvc tube
Fittings in order of front to rear:
3" Tee (alter by adding hold through for muzzle brake, I used a lathe for this)
3" to 4" adapter bushing (alter by removing lip inside so 3" pipe slides through)
4" to 6" adapter bushing
6" pipe to 6" male thread adapter
6" female thread to 6" pipe adapter
8 feet cut from the 6" tube listed above for pressure chamber
6" schedule 40 pipe-to-pipe connector
6" to 4" bushing (alter to remove lip inside so 4" pipe slides through)
4" schedule 40 pipe-to-pipe connector
4" to (smaller) bushing
(smaller) to 1" NPT female thread bushing
1" NPT pipe 9" long extending to the rear from the last bushing
Going back to where we had 4" pipe now,
4" to 6" bushing (only glue to 4" pipe, and perhaps sand down outside slightly)
6" schedule 40 pipe-to-pipe connector (do not glue to bushing)
6" schedule 40 pipe approximately 6-8" long, so next fitting fits up flush as shown
6" pipe to 6" NPT female thread adapter
6" NPT threaded screw-in cap (alter with 1" clearance hole in center, add fittings for fill & trigger)
1" NPT threaded reducer tee (this goes onto the 1" pipe coming from the breech)
Reducer bushing going in reducer tee to get it down to 1/8 NPT female
1/8 NPT male 90 degree 1/4" air tube connection
The following gets mounted in the rear screw-in cap, using it as a solid wall and providing the air hose connection on the rear for filling:
1/4" air tube connection to 1/4 NPT female (may need a few pieces to adapt this)
1/4 NPT male air hose coupler fitting
Back to the tee, coming straight back in-line with the centerline:
1" NPT sprinkler valve, modified to remove solenoid for faster direct triggering
1/8" NPT male 90 degree 1/4 air tube connection (threaded in where solenoid was)
Several feet of 1/4" air tube coming from the sprinkler valve's trigger back through cap
1/4" air tube to 1/4 NPT fitting
1/4 NPT tee
Pressure gauge off the side of the tee
1/4 NPT male-male short adapter
air blaster screwed on as the final piece, the trigger

Prime and glue everything (except the threaded joints, and where the rear "can" slips over the sprinkler valve area) and make sure to use thread sealing tape on all threaded connections. The piston could be 3D printed as shown above, although currently I am just using a rubber cap for 4" tube glued over a 4" cap glued to a short piece of 4" tube, and then a 4" to 5" clay pipe rubber adapter that is flipped backwards so its larger diameter end (roughly 6" diameter outside - fitting the pressure chamber) is right around where the 4" tube cap is. The flat face of the 4" rubber cap is what seals against the end of the 3" barrel - I set the gap by putting a roll of duct tape in the breech, along with the piston, screwing the glued bushings into the front of the pressure chamber, and then taking the not-yet-glued 3" barrel and sliding it in until it hit, and gluing it there. After it cured, I unscrewed the barrel with its front bushings at the front 6" thread (the muzzle brake allows a smaller tube to pass through for leverage for unscrewing), and removed the roll of duct tape, leaving the piston with a few inches clearance to travel forward/backward between the breech and barrel. The inner end of the 3" barrel was carefully sanded very flat and perpendicular to the barrel's axis, so the valve would seal against it well. Procedure is to connect the air hose and allow it to pressurize to at least 20PSI (perhaps use a ball valve to control filling) so the piston seats to the barrel, and then load your projectile. If you load a projectile with zero pressure, the piston won't be up against the end of the barrel, and any wadding you have behind the projectile (I like using blocks of pillow foam) will expand out the back of the 3" barrel, preventing the piston from sealing against it. If the piston starts slightly pressurized so it's already sealed, then this isn't an issue. Once loaded and fully pressurized (I run 90PSI based on my air compressor's limitations) then when the air blaster is squeezed, the sprinkler valve's diaphragm now has low pressure behind it that you just vented, so the high pressure from inside can pop it open and flow out fast. This means that inside the breech, the pressure is holding the piston over the 3" barrel for starters, with 90PSI both ahead and behind the piston since it isn't a perfect seal, so it wants to stay forward as a cork in the only hole it sees low pressure, the 3" barrel. But when the sprinkler valve dumps out the air from behind the piston, now the piston has 6" diameter of low pressure behind it, 3" of low pressure ahead in the barrel, but the rest of the storage chamber is still pressurized to push back on the front of it, so it incredibly quickly will move to the rear, opening wide for all the chamber pressure to flow out the front.

Sorry for the rushed write-up, I just wanted to get a bunch of this info added to start with so it's at least listed.

Video of test firing (sorry for vertical video - I wasn't the one filming)
https://youtu.be/_vxRjVACCRQ

Update 18MAY2017: added "rifler print" .stl files for tool that holds 6 pipe cutter replacement wheels (Plumb Works #694-3873) to pull through 3" schedule 40 PVC and cut rifling. Added "valve metric.stl" which is printed in flexible TPU and has tested successfully so far.

description.text:
I could not get a level build plate very easily with my stock Y-Carriage (actually never got it level, but good enough to print this) and The Wanhao Duplicator i3/Monoprice Maker Y carriage by reprapchampion is too large to print on this printer. While, I could have easily purchased a replacement metal carriage from reprapchampion or another source, I wanted to refresh my CAD chops, see if this could be done, and see if the results would provide better prints.
I redesigned it such that the main structure is printed separately from the wings which will support the posts from the heated bed. To join them together, I added a dovetail pocket in the main carriage plate and dovetail tabs in the post supports.

The print has some flex to it, but is more rigid than the original steel y carriage.
It is also nearly 60 grams lighter, so we can add an additional smooth rod bearing under the right side of the carriage without increasing the weight of the assembly.

Let me know in the comments if you print this, have any questions, what you think, or any problems you encounter. The original is licensed GPL, so this production inherits this license. Please make sure you provide attribution to any remixes.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed this with 6 bottom and top layers and 4 perimeter shells using Simplify3d, with a default printing speed of 80mm/s. I printed all four of the tabs at the same time, duplicating the model.

Use an X-acto or similar to clip the tab corners for easier starting of the dovetail tabs into their slots on the main body

I had to make some minor cuts (very small, like 0.5 mm) with an X-acto knife on the leading edge of the dove tail to get the tabs to slide into the slot.

The carriage is about 5-6 mm thick and the original M4x8 screws will work to attach this to the bearing slides and Y belt action, but a set of longer M4x12 bolts would be better to avoid the risk of stripping the aluminum of the bearing slides.

I do not recommend removing and reseting the tabs over an over again, as this will loosen the fit between the tabs and the slots.

Tabs and main body mostly attached Carriage attached for first test 3DBenchy Test in progress 3DBenchy complete

Designed using FreeCAD 0.16

I designed this in FreeCAD 0.16, using the PDF diagram provided by reprepchampion for measurement of the bolt hole locations and overall dimensions of the carriage. The main body printed in about 6 hours, and the tabs were completed in just under two hours.
The STL for the main body and yPlateTabAdjusted can be printed as is and should not require any supports. If you modify the design and export a new STL for the tab, you will need to rotate the STL for the tab 180 degrees around either the X, or the Y axis, and recenter in order to print in the correct orientation in order to avoid supports. I also recommend rotating the tab by 45 degrees about the z axis so that the bottom and top print at 45 degrees to the walls, and use an triangular infill, or rectangular infill which will sit at 45 degrees to the walls

remixed_from.author: zennmaster
remixed_from.title: Z-probe holder for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed-level

description.text:
This is auto bed-leveling sytem for Ultimaker. It will also fit derevative printers like Joysmaker or Dreammaker.
The main idea is to mount z-min endstop to the print head. It will probe 4 points of the bed before the print. All moves will be transformed according the bed aligment. Servo serves here to lift the probe up during the print. Watch how it works: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x8eqSQNAyro UPDATE 16.02.2014:
Use new firmware version
https://github.com/Bevaz/Marlin/tree/Auto_level_2.00
It allows to interactively set the extend and retract angles of z-probe via LCD controller. Also the probe will be extended only once during bed probing. UPDATE 11.01.2015
Firmare synced with latest Marlin can be found at:
https://github.com/Bevaz/Marlin/tree/Auto_level_3.00

To build it you need
1) Servo sg90 or similair.
2) Microswitch
3) Connectors
4) Wires
5) Printed parts Build steps:
1) Printed parts: servo mount and probe mount
2) Wire servo. Connect it to the board (see picture)
3) Wire microswitch. Replace min z-endstop with it.
4) Mount everything to the print head.
5) Note that upper point of the probe is the maximum clockwise position of the servo. Attach the probe accordingly.
6) Download Marlin firmware from https://github.com/Bevaz/Marlin/tree/Auto_level_2.00 and upload to the board. It is derevative from Ultimaker firmware. So it will work with original Ultimaker.
7) Modify start GCODE in Cura:
...
G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops
G28 Z0 ;move Z to min endstops
G29 ;probe Z to min endstops
G1 X0 Y0 Z15.0 F{travel_speed} ;move the platform down 15mm
...
8) To align the offset of the probe from the nozzle adjust macro Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER in Marlin Configuration.h
Or use LCD module. Menu->Control->Motion->Z-Offset. You can also save this settings in EEPROM.
9) To set extend and retract angles of z-probe interactively use LCD module: Menu->Control->Motion->Z-extend angle and Menu->Control->Motion->Z-retract angle. You can also save this settings in EEPROM.
10) Enjoy and forget about bed-leveling nightmare.

comments.text:
Try to increase the value #define PROBE_SERVO_DEACTIVATION_DELAY 300 in Marlin firmware. Or turn it off completely. Some times it can occur. Servo doesn't have enough time to get into position when it is turned of by firmware.
Soon I will post some updates to the firmware. So the probe will be engaged only once during probing. And it would be possible to set the angles of servo from LCD controller.

title: Kenner Star Wars Action Figure Lightsaber

description.text:
For everyone who has a lost vintage Kenner Star Wars action figure lightsaber. I realized that a couple of the light sabers in my vintage figures had broken tips on the end so figured why not design a replacement for a 3D printer!

I tried to print these in one piece but nothing I could do would come out nice and smooth so I had to cut it into two halves. Print both then glue with your favorite gluing method. I have found that some of the vintage figures have a small lip on the inside of the hand when you go to insert these so just be aware.

The pic with the two out of the figure shows the original on the right and printed piece on the left. I printed these at 0.10 resolution but you should be able to get away with others.

Have fun!

remixed_from.title: Anet a8 X-axis cable chain with z end-stop

title: Anet a8 X-axis cable chain X motor mount beefed up a bit

description.text:
I had a few issues printing the stellar thing: "Anet a8 X-axis cable chain with z end-stop"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2115095
by The Random Engineer
http://www.thingiverse.com/The_Random_Engineer/about

I had a bunch of problems getting the chain connection end to print very well...
Eventually I figured out printing it with the top side against the build plate, (like when you print chains) the links printed perfectly.

I also had a problem drilling at tapping the end stop. I was trying to use the SAE hardware I already had, so when drilling and tapping for 8-32 screws, the end stop holder broke off. I doubt it was designed for that, so I added a much bigger support flange on this one.

I also thought it would look better if the top of the it was full so you could hide more of the wiring, and I made a 45 degree channel inside to help with redirecting wiring. Someday I could design an attachment for more chain to get it to an electronics case.

While I was editing I added 45 degree lateral supports, probably not necessary, but why not? and beefed up the back plate.

I ended up using longer screws to mount it on the motor, as the stock ones barley make it to the motor as is.

I also liked the bigger stopper with measured markings from
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172190
made by
http://www.thingiverse.com/klownius/about

After printing a couple of these, I had a problem with the chain sagging in a hot enclosure, so I made a new thing that has a long link support that should hold up to the temperatures better, and I printed this one in ABS.

comments.text: Nice work. I used the long chain link part from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2104821 with this mount. It adds some flexibility to the mount as well.

title: Robo 3D R1+ Threaded Rod Spool Holder

description.text:
Another remix of a great top mount spool holder for the ROBO 3D R1+

This design utilizes a 5/16" threaded rod and spool adaptors ( with skateboard bearings) to make switching spools easy and let them roll with little resistance.

While this does require the use of different adaptors for different brands of filament, and some times different spool styles within a brand, in a pinch I have used a section of 1" pvc to lesson the tension on the spool.

This is technically the second iteration as I have added more material at the base for more support. Two versions are included, base and one with holes.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed horizontally, you might get a little bit of oozing from the bridging at the top, but it should clean up pretty quick after a layer or two. It would probably print just as well or better vertically, but just make sure you have good layer adhesion. You wouldn't want it to delaminate and drop your propane canister on the concrete.

description.text:
My dad's shop is always a mess, but the one thing that is always where it is supposed to be is his propane torch. I guess when you are grinding and welding on metal all day, a thin-walled metal container of highly flammable gas is not the kind of thing you want to leave lying around.

In that light, I put together this quick holder for my newly purchased propane torch. The hole is 79mm and should fit all the Bernzomatic 14oz canisters. It's a simple, but long print (about 6 hours at my speeds). It's intended to be screwed to a wall or bench with #10 (5mm) countersunk screws..

Printer:

Voron/Ultimaker Hybrid (DIY)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.40

Infill:

20 or >

Notes:

Printed horizontally, you might get a little bit of oozing from the bridging at the top, but it should clean up pretty quick after a layer or two. It would probably print just as well or better vertically, but just make sure you have good layer adhesion. You wouldn't want it to delaminate and drop your propane canister on the concrete.

comments.text: Exactly what I was looking for.  These torches are excellent for starting wood stoves.  But, having a torch constantly being knocked over in the house does not promote a safe environment.  This holder meets the need perfectly.  Thanks.

description.text:
This is a remix I modeled by subtracting out rweaving's molds, adding some walls, and giving the walls a slight draft outward. I intend to use it to create silicone molds which will hopefully be a little more cleanable than plastic parts. Since I have yet to try it, this is still a work in progress.

I made the original chocolate bunny and it worked very well.

EDIT: I added a low volume variation (two more STL files) in hopes of minimizing the amount of silicone needed.

I take no credit whatsoever. I'm simply sharing a fan art model from MyMiniFactory: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/starcraft-kerrigan-statue-10432. MyMiniFactory has an open sharing policy so I believe I can post it here as long as I give proper credits. I have yet to attempt to print this model. The picture was also taken from the original artist. Looks super challenging. Share your printing experience!

The artist was pretty obviously trying to reproduce this official model:
https://www.sideshowtoy.com/collectibles/starcraft-kerrigan-sideshow-collectibles-200312/

The tiles I was finding on here were a bit thick for my liking, long print times and hard to modify.

These tiles are thin enough to be separated into other shapes using a knife or brute force if you need (eg 2x1).

They also print quickly and are easy to store (we found lindt chocolate block boxes are perfect).

I'll be adding more tiles here as I develop them. I try to keep tiles easy to print with low resolution because you often need a lot quickly.

There's also wall sections here (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2255700)

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

In my craftman toolbox with ball bearing slides, there are little clips at the back of the drawers which keep the drawer shut.  One of these clips broke.  After not finding anyone publishing one on thinginverse, I decided to make my own.  I copied an unbroken one in solidworks, and printed it.  It works perfectly - you can't tell from the original.  If you need one, here ya go.

title: Grippy shell for Nook Glowlight Plus

description.text:
I recently bought a Nook Glowlight Plus to replace a dead Nook Simpletouch Glow and quickly found that I hated the new design. Instead of a nice grippy back the new model has got a slippery metal back which is hard to hang on to, and even worse the edges of the case are rather sharp and irritating to hold. I can't imagine who thought this was a good idea, but maybe it was cheaper to make.

I measured and modeled the Glowlight Plus and designed a shell to be printed in a material like TPU that would provide a nice grippy back and would also fit over those sharp edges - if it fits well it would fix most of the complaints with the new design.

But I was also more motivated to see if I could take apart and fix the Simpletouch Glow, and ended up fixing it by replacing the battery, so the Glowlight Plus is getting returned. So my design for a shell has never been printed even though I believe it would fit. I'm sharing it in case it would help someone else. The shell is 1mm thick.

If someone wants to try this and needs some minor changes to make it fit I can do that.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print in a semi-flexible material like TPU (Ninjaflex would be too flexible and saggy). Support is probably needed for the lip going around at the top and can't hurt for the curved base and two holes. Like all printing with flexible filament you'll have to slow down the print speed significantly.

description.text:
A 3 piece bolt pen designed for a Parker ball point refill. The mechanism is pretty self explanatory in the attached gif. Also works just fine with any generic ink cartridge and spring if you snip the cartridge to size. Simply insert the cartridge and spring into the casing. Put the bolt on top and screw the cap on and you're good to write!

When printing the casing I recommend to print it vertically if possible (with the tip on the printer base). This will prevent warping and negate the need to have any building material on the inside (which can be very difficult to remove).

See the Reddit post here:
https://www.reddit.com/r/3Dprinting/comments/65ep1v/designed_and_printed_a_pen_i_cannibalized_the/?st=j1n0a32n&sh=868f6695

description.text:
DIY...In Space! This is a standard PockeCube micro satellite frame for classroom or desktop use. The unit is a standard 1p in size (50mm x 50mm x 50mm). With this framework, you can build your own satellite using a variety of ultra small logic systems such as Edison or Tinyduino. Mount plates for both micro-controllers are in the bundle.

The bundle includes a top plate, frame, bottom plate with mounting holes, and mounting plates for Edison (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13045) and Tinyduino (https://tinycircuits.com/pages/tinyduino-overview) SOCs. A blank mounting plate is added as well for your own electronics designs.

Mounting the plates is done with M2 hardware. Two kits from Sparkfun (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13187) should provide the basics. Hardware store may have M2 components in stock or they may be able to order them for you.

Notes:

Use a raft when printing the frame as the corners do not provide enough support to print without one. All other parts can be printed with skirts unless you have issues with bed curling. In that case a raft will be needed.

Cleanup

Parts can be cleaned with a small file set and a hobby knife.

Origins

I created this as a simple model in Google Sketchup an printed the first prototypes using Shapeways. After transitioning to Autodesk Fusion 360, I was able to exact a bit more control over the details and develope the recessed solar panel areas. Later, I added an ANET A8 printer to my shop and the final product was created.

The Square has an outer diameter of 150mm.
Measure it. with a caliper, note that Value for X and Y

Calculate
Exprected Value / Measured Value x actual Steps for that Axis.

To Read the actual Steps, Start Pronterface, connect to your Printer.
Enter M503
Look for the Line M92 X98.45 Y110.13 Z402.3 E403.00

Example:
U expect 150mm
U measured for X 144.3mm

Calculate:
150/144.3 * 98,45 = ~102.339

Do the same for Y

Enter in Pronterface M92 X102.339 Y110.13 Z402.3 E403.00
Then Enter M500 to save it to the EEPROM
Enter M503 again to see if the new values are saved,

This offset laser mount is designed specifically for the 23mm laser pictured. It should however fit anything the same diameter. I also plan on releasing a 26mm version soon for my flashlight.

The mount is one piece, and clamps around the laser, with the open ends of the ring being the two halves of my proprietary magpul slot sized plug.

There is no tolerance added for the laser, and you will have to sand the inside of the ring for most lasers, as they can vary from 22.5 to 23.0mm. Sand until it barely fits, and it should be nice and snug.

If you want this in other sizes, or just want a simple adapter sleeve, i'd be willing to try to design it for whatever tip you can provide.

description.text:
My first thingiverse upload, please be gentle if I've messed up.

A system for dealing with cardboard miniatures that are supposed to be flying where you might want variable heights. The flying stands socket into the pawn bases.

The sizing was determined by what worked on my Micro3D printer, using their Tough 3D ink. I imagine if tolerances were too tight or loose, you could adjust it by scaling the stands up or down a percentage point or two.

So far, I've provided 4 different stand heights, short, medium, tall, and "hover". If you wanted something taller, I don't think it would compromise things much to scale the z-axis up.

On the Micro3D, these are all printable without any supports.

As I print out miniatures, I'll try to put similar sockets in their bases, so that I can just stick them on top of the same stands.

Other things I've created that have compatible sockets in the base:

  • Curved Paper Miniature Base
  • Familiar Double Pawn Bases

(I started by modifying the wonderful Pawn Base from Mapembert to add the socket.)

Printer:

Micro3D

No

Resolution:

150 microns

High

Notes:

On the Micro3D, with Tough 3D ink, these print well, and socket snugly. If they're a little tight at first, they loosen up with a little repetition.

description.text:
Ever have trouble finding the o-ring you need for a project? Well, with this script you can specify the size you need and either generate the o-ring itsself (for printing in flexible material) or you can generate a mold to make the o-ring out of silicone or whatever. For more than you ever wanted to know about O-rings (including what the standard sizes are), check out:
http://www.allsealsinc.com/ParcoO-RingSizeChart.pdf NOTE: The accuracy and printability of the results are untested! UPDATE:
Added version 1.1 which:
  • Makes molds that actually work with "minionizing"
  • Removed mold flaw in outside surface of o-ring
  • Customizer settings are better without so many sliders
  • Added customizer setting for resolution
  • Mold key is bigger
  • Code is more modularized and readable for use in other projects

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9ag0cTPsVtk

As time progresses, hobby electronics are becoming more and more complex. Well, at least mine are... My last design had over 400 surface mount components and the usual "solder blob and place" technique was getting tedious. So, instead of spending several hundred dollars on a basic stencil printer I decided to make one that ran me about $30.

Assembly

This stencil printer requires a only a few ball bearings and nuts/bolts. All mounting holes were designed for 4-40 size bolt. The entire design is mounted on a .25 inch Lexan sheet.

We often had the need to hang towels and clothing up for drying inside a sailing boat. All yachts we have been on seem to have similar handrails but it was always quite tricky to fix something to them. Standard clothes pegs tend to jump off. That's why I made this special hanger peg. It prints completely and in one piece and works ok but is a bit weak when printed in PLA. It tends to loose power in the clamp so I will soon come up with a heavy duty version using a clothes peg spring.
Depending on the printer it may need separating of theclaws with a knife. OpenSCAD file is included but by using a sinus-function and loop for the shape it is extremely slow.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
My wife's boss plays the piano and I couldn't find a version I was happy about being easy to print and still look good. This was my first remix and it took a few days. I sliced it up and made it so you can print with no supports and minimal infill. I printed mine at 0.2mm and 10% infill.

Be careful with the legs, so for those I would probably do 3 shells at slow speed to make sure the layers adhere nicely.

The front page is so large because I actually embossed and painted it in. I removed it so you can just carefully paint in your own name and it should look ok.

Once you're done print the individual pieces check for fit and adjust with some minor sanding. The stand support for the lid might be a bit large but take a dremel or drill bit and carefully adjust it so the stand fits the slots. Other than that just use some simple super glue.

Additional:
After I superglued. I covered they keys with blue painters tape and used acrylic paint spray to paint the entire piano in black and the strings separately in gold. Then 3 layers of hobby clear lacquer.

If you guys have any suggestions let me know. Enjoy!

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

0.1, 0.2

Piano legs

description.text:
Following on from the Eachine TVL1000 camera mount for a 9g servo here is a version that will support HS1177 style cameras.

This mount allows you to easily connect an FPV camera to a servo fro a super easy pan gimbal for your model.

There are two versions with different sized holes for the servo output shaft so pick the one that will work for you.

I print using ABS and use acetone to soften the plastic for mounting to the servo to make sure the teeth are engaged to support.

Happy printing!

title: Multiple Weight Bucket Holder for Mechanical Clock

description.text:
For my mechanical clock I did not like how tall the provided bucket was, so I created a new bucket which is shorter but then made these holders so that I could put multiple of them on the same design.
I think it makes it look cool, too.

These mounts are compatible with the default Weight_Pulley_Hook provided in the original mechanical clock by TheGoofy at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:328569
And they hold my bucket provided at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2256085

Note: on the 3 bucket holder, the outer two are slightly lower than the middle one. I figured this would make it easy to make them hang level. If someone wants one with an even height offset or more of a height offset I can make make one.

description.text: The Canon FD 200mm F2.8 has no mount option. I printed a simple mount for a permament installation to watch birds. A former version of this can be seen here: http://www.storch-bleckmar.de/blog/index.php/about

This project is designed to be a test rig for a solar tracking experiment run out of Imperial College London. The experiment entailed tested different algorithms run on the devices to see which would produce the most energy.

It was made using a combination of 3d printing and laser cutting.
More information and a link to the paper will follow if/when it's published.
In the interim, feel free to ask and questions in the comments.

Full credit to Simona Ciocoiu (@SimonaCiocoiu) for the design!

A stand for tablets (and smartphones) with customizable size and geometry.

This thing should print without any special precautions like support etc. Just create the STL with the customizer, slice and print it.  
When using the customizations in the advanced tab you must take special care to choose reasonable combinations of parameters.

This part fits the USB-C (to USB, charger and HDMI) adapter. A MacBook can then slide into the stand and then automatically plug into the adapter which connects all devices. HDMI screen is needed since the MacBook screen remains closed.

description.text:
...straight from the Vatican.

This is a recreation of the reliquary Hellboy hands to Abe before he dives in to a whole heap of trouble. The clear tube is a section of plastic test-tube.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

This has been designed so no supports are required.

Finishing

Print the parts at a nice high resolution. I vapour smoothed the pieces, which worked really well. The top needs to be glued to the lid.

The clear tube is about 60mm/2.5" cut from a 25 x 140mm (40ml) plastic test tube (see picture below).

To finish the parts were sprayed gold, roughly brushed with black acrylic and wiped clean. The bone was painted using acrylic paints to look like bone.
Modelled in Sketchup, mesh cleaned up in Silo 3D then the detail added in Sculptris.

Here is a Stormbolter for Warhammer 40k. It comes with a circular magazine. Check out the standard version : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2254199 =).

I haven't a 3D printer, so I could not test the rendering :/

Enjoy

description.text:
This replacement spool holder is designed for 2.3kg spools (iso_544) which are ~100mm width. It also have a ridge so a 70mm spool (original bq spools) stay in place and doesn't wiggle around.

This holder will acomodate almost any spool, as long it has a 30mm or bigger hub, wich are the majority, with the exeption of taulman's spools.

V2 Updated!

  • tightened mounting clearances, son it stands horizontal (previous version have a singly downwards slope)
  • Improved 70mm ridge position, so it docent interferes with the 100mm spool.
  • Rotated part so when imported into the slicer is ready to print.

Printer:

BQ Witbox 0.8 nozzle

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.6

Infill:

20

Notes:

Support neeeded for the mounting ridge, altought it will break away quite easlily (at least slic3r pilars pattern)

I have printed this part with a 0.8mm nozzle and 0.6layer, so the part its pretty strong.

After our normal supplier ran out out of filament, the only filament wich we could get our hands at was a 2.3kg spool.

That spool almost fitted in our old spool holder, so we just keep printing.

After a while, our old spool holder (was also printed) broke, so we decided to design a version wich can acomodate these spools and wouln't break so easily (we solved the latter part simply printing it with a 0.8 nozzle)

title: RepRapPro Mendel Cooling Fan Bracket (Parametric)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I liked this cooling fan holder by ajayre, but wanted to put the fan in a different position, so i have re-implimented the design in OpenSCAD and made it parametric.   
The spacing of the accessory screw plate is fixed, but you can modify the length and position of the arm, and the size of the screw holes.  
The fan bracket, you can now edit the neck length and the spacing between the screw holes to fit other sizes of fan.

You will need 20mm or so M3 nuts and bolts, one to secure the hinge, two to attach the fan to the holder.   
Designed to fit over the 4 "accessory" bolts in the top of the RepRapPro Mendel X carriage.   
Lengths of the various arms, and screw holes are adjustable in the scad files.

title: Raspberry pi zero w + rpicam: Simple box

description.text:
Just a simple box to contain the Raspberry Pi Zero W + a RPIcam module. Two versions of the frontplate is included: One with my logo, and one without. Assembly of the two parts need no screws. Simply press the two parts together. For more rugged use, I suggest you either glue the parts together, use a rubber band, or add mounts for screws.

I only needed access to the power USB port, so no access to 2nd USB or HDMI. If needed it's just a matter of modifying the baseplate.

Printed on Anet A8

comments.text:
This is perfect... minimal open ports... basically only power.
Could you include a logo-less cover plate without the camera?

title: Guide doigts Mac - Mac Keyboard keyguard

description.text:
Keyguard for standard Mac keyboard.

You can print or laser cut the top part, and print the runners (two of each angle runner and straights) that allow the keyguard to slide neatly over the keys. Slide the runners into place and glue the keyguard on top.

The runners are optional, as you can use the keyguard without them, but they stop any unwanted movement.

Also available on OnShape (search for Mac keyboard keyguard).

Guide doigts pour clavier Mac conçu par un étudiant de l'université de Bordeaux.

Le guide doigts peut être imprimé ou découpé avec une découpeuse laser, ou une CNC.

Le guide doigt peut être simplement placé par dessus les touches du clavier, ou alors vous pouvez également imprimer les guides qui coulissent le long du clavier et maintiennent le guide-doigts immobile.

Sur la photo, on voit un guide-doigts en acrylique transparent avec les guides coulissants blancs sur la partie alphabétique, tandis que sur la partie numérique on a le guide seul, sans les parties coulissantes, découpé dans du bois.

Si vous souhaitez imprimer les parties coulissantes, il faut imprimer deux fois chaque "angle Runner" et six fois le "straight runner".

Fichiers disponibles sur OnShape (chercher Guide-doigts mac).
